channel.title: Muscle toning
channel.description:
What's the best way to tone muscles that are already pretty big? Just doing lots of reps on low weight or some other way.
Thanks.

item.title: Muscle toning
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Since I started working out!

My workouts don’t consist of heaps though, but they’re better than most people’s nonetheless.
I simply do squats, deadlifts, press/military press (it’s far easier to squeeze the glutes with the feet together, imo), bench press, lateral rows and chinups.
I’m getting a skinfold test done on Tuesday, so maybe I’ll post my bodyfat percentage after that’s done. At the moment I weigh about 78kg.

Read full topic

item.title: Muscle toning
item.dc:creator: @Tico135 Tico
item.description:
@Tico135 wrote:

First off, it kills my eyes that Lothy just used the word “stabiliser muscles.” What he was referring to was core. Doing free weights is a lot better for core muscles, but if you really care all that much more just do core workouts (which I actually find pretty fun). Seeing as core strength improves balance, durability, and abdominal strength at the same time, it’s a great workout.

P.S. since when does Lothy care/know about working out?

Read full topic

item.title: Muscle toning
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

How do you eat your rolled oats, Daniel and Lothy? Do you mix it with water or milk?

I put 1 cup of rolled oats in my blender and grind them down to a reasonably fine powder. I then put 1 cup of skim milk in along with 1 banana, and grind again. After that, I add 30 grams of protein powder, grind again. Finally, I add another 1 cup of skim milk, grind, and then drink.

It’s awesome.

[quote=“jme, post:30, topic:338268”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=434659.msg3192701#msg3192701 date=1272417752]

Hmm ok, so the general idea is that I should focus more on cardio in order to make my muscles look more outlined and toned, rather than big blocks of fat and muscle I have now.

What sort of weights should I be lifting? For the past few months I have been lifting about 45-50kg on weight machines, and benching around 30kg. I generally lift whatever weight I can for around 12 reps/4 sets.

Thanks for the very helpful replies!

Ditch the machines and move to free weights. Machine strength isn’t functional strength, because the machine balances the weight for you. This means that any ‘strength’ gains you make on a machine aren’t usable for real-world purposes (such as physical work).
[/quote]

I somewhat disagree. Or at least, machines are nice for a begginer because you will be using muscles you don’t normally use. The burn I got from some machines gave me great ideas for working out at home.

I love working out. It’s very addictive. But unfortunately I stopped for a long time and I’m having a hard time getting back into it. You really feel like shit when you lose everything you worked so hard to gain. And it doesn’t take long for that to happen. [/quote]
The problem with the machine weights is that they balance the weight for the user, keeping it in the correct path of motion.
Usually, stabilisation of the weight to ensure proper technique is the responsibility of the person training. When a person does squats as opposed to using a leg press machine, they’re building up all of their little stabiliser muscles too because they’re actively balancing the weight. The guy on the leg press misses out on building these muscles.

What this means is that a guy who can squat 200kg can leg press that or more. Throw a guy who can leg press 200kg into a squat rack for some squats and he might be lucky to squat 50kg… but more than likely just the bar if he has never done it before.
Working with barbell exercises builds strength that you will be able to make use of outside of the gym.

Read full topic

Hmm ok, so the general idea is that I should focus more on cardio in order to make my muscles look more outlined and toned, rather than big blocks of fat and muscle I have now.

What sort of weights should I be lifting? For the past few months I have been lifting about 45-50kg on weight machines, and benching around 30kg. I generally lift whatever weight I can for around 12 reps/4 sets.

Thanks for the very helpful replies!
[/quote]

item.title: Muscle toning
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Original Daniel, post:22, topic:338268”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=434659.msg3192463#msg3192463 date=1272409061]
Boxing 4 nights a week isn’t really easy, in my opinion, presuming that’s 4 hours per week. In fact, that’s actually quite a lot of work.
[/quote]

6-8 hours a week, but I wouldn’t call it work. Once you get into exercising it feels great. It hurts like a bitch while you do it, but you feel awesome after.

Even so I was losing it fairly easy just with the decent diet before I boxed, I mean I drank on weekends and still cut fat.

Just need to cut out processed stuff. The less processed the better. Orange > orange juice > orange cake etc

You can eat as much as you want, as long as it’s not crap.

Oats cost me like 90c a bag and last me a while, and 2kg of brown rice is only like $4-5. Eating healthy is easy and you save shit loads of money.[/quote]
Well, 6 - 8 hours is a lot of time each week. Congratulations for doing so well.

Regarding rolled oats and rice, I agree. I’ve always wondered why more university students don’t make these two things larger parts of their diet, considering how crying poor we all seem to be.

Read full topic

item.title: Muscle toning
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Mr.Chris, post:18, topic:338268”]Hmm ok, so the general idea is that I should focus more on cardio in order to make my muscles look more outlined and toned, rather than big blocks of fat and muscle I have now.

What sort of weights should I be lifting? For the past few months I have been lifting about 45-50kg on weight machines, and benching around 30kg. I generally lift whatever weight I can for around 12 reps/4 sets.

Thanks for the very helpful replies![/quote]
Ditch the machines and move to free weights. Machine strength isn’t functional strength, because the machine balances the weight for you. This means that any ‘strength’ gains you make on a machine aren’t usable for real-world purposes (such as physical work).

Visit http://stronglifts.com/stronglifts-5x5-beginner-strength-training-program/ for a well balanced strength training program. The site is a gold mine when it comes to strength training and fat loss.

Read full topic

item.title: Muscle toning
item.dc:creator: @Tico135 Tico
item.description:
@Tico135 wrote:

Well it all depends on what you’re going for. If you’re looking for size, then you’re looking for a weight that you can do about 8 reps with (you should be feeling a big burn on the last 3 reps). But yes, if you’re looking to tone, go for a lot more cardio to lose your fat.

Read full topic

item.title: Muscle toning
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

kCal = Calories, with a capital C. The capital C is important, because calories and Calories are actually two different units apparently, which I wasn’t aware of until I began doing conversions between kilojoules and kcals a while ago.

[quote=“Original Daniel, post:15, topic:338268”]I found it pretty easy… I let myself go a bit after high school because I didn’t have a free personal trainer 4-5 times a week. I went from 82-88 in that time, started eating better and dropped a bit with only a tiny bit of muscle loss since I wasn’t lifting anymore, started boxing 4 nights a week with some lifting and I almost had my old arms and 6 pack back within just a couple months before work got in the way.

I do eat pretty well though. Oats and fruit for breakfast, fruit, nuts, salmon and brown rice during the day, no soft drink etc.[/quote]
Boxing 4 nights a week isn’t really easy, in my opinion, presuming that’s 4 hours per week. In fact, that’s actually quite a lot of work.

la­wl:

i dont eat that well, sure i try to get some veggies in but i generally dont give a damn about my diet, and im totally skinny

My brother is like that. Does fuck all each and every day when it comes to physical activity, and still manages to stay at a certain weight.

Read full topic

item.title: Muscle toning
item.dc:creator: @Original_Daniel Original Daniel
item.description:
@Original_Daniel wrote:

I found it pretty easy… I let myself go a bit after high school because I didn’t have a free personal trainer 4-5 times a week. I went from 82-88 in that time, started eating better and dropped a bit with only a tiny bit of muscle loss since I wasn’t lifting anymore, started boxing 4 nights a week with some lifting and I almost had my old arms and 6 pack back within just a couple months before work got in the way.

I do eat pretty well though. Oats and fruit for breakfast, fruit, nuts, salmon and brown rice during the day, no soft drink etc.

Read full topic

i lost 10kg in 3 months without doing anything (other than work, which might have helped). beat that

Lothy:

For the record though, most people will only manage to lose 1 pound of fat per week (which is 3500 kCal) without also losing too much muscle mass.

Is that 3,500,000 calories? If not, why is there a ‘k’?

Also, do all the calories you eat necessarily get absorbed by your body? I’d expect that some remain unabsorbed and end up in your feces.

Personally, I see bodybuilding for the sake of bodybuilding (ie, aesthetics) as something for morons to waste their time with.

item.title: Muscle toning
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I’ve been cutting for a while now and, contrary to what Original Daniel said, it isn’t easy.
I could probably drop 4.4 - 11 pounds (2 - 5kg) overnight using diuretics (diuretics dehydrate your body, almost completely eliminating water weight) – people in sports (boxing, MMA, other martial arts) with weight classes do it all the time before fights; that’s weight loss right there, and fuck yeah it’s easy.
But fat loss, which is what this topic is concerned with, isn’t easy. You can expect to lose 2 pounds of fat per week at best. If you lose any more than that then you are most certainly losing muscle tissue.
For the record though, most people will only manage to lose 1 pound of fat per week (which is 3500 kCal) without also losing too much muscle mass.

Yz85Racer is kinda on the right track, presuming I understand what he’s getting at. Why exactly are you looking to reduce bodyfat?
There’s nothing wrong with sitting around 15% bodyfat, which is where the average man is.
Personally, I see bodybuilding for the sake of bodybuilding (ie, aesthetics) as something for morons to waste their time with.
Your muscles aren’t really that functional, you just look like a musclebound dickhead.

If you’re going to do it, do it because of a real reason – whether it’s to become more proficient at some sport you do, or perhaps for the sake of work (particularly anyone here in the armed forces for their country).

Read full topic
